segment.source: Much like OpenGL ES 2.0, the compiled shaders in Direct3D must be associated with a drawing context.
segment.target: Much like OpenGL ES 2.0, the compiled shaders in Direct3D must be associated with a drawing context.

segment.source: However, Direct3D does not have the concept of a shader program object per se; instead, you must assign the shaders directly to a ID3D11DeviceContext.
segment.target: However, Direct3D does not have the concept of a shader program object per se; instead, you must assign the shaders directly to a ID3D11DeviceContext.

segment.source: This step follows the OpenGL ES 2.0 process for creating and binding shader objects, and provides you with the corresponding API behaviors in Direct3D.

segment.source: In Direct3D, shaders are not compiled during run-time; they are always compiled to CSO files when the rest of the program is compiled.
segment.target: In Direct3D, shaders are not compiled during run-time; they are always compiled to CSO files when the rest of the program is compiled.

segment.source: When you compile your app with Microsoft Visual Studio, the HLSL files are compiled to CSO (.cso) files that your app must load.

segment.source: Make sure you include these CSO files with your app when you package it!

segment.source: OpenGL ES 2.0 has the notion of a shader "program", which serves as the interface between the main program running on the CPU and the shaders, which are executed on the GPU.
segment.target: OpenGL ES 2.0 has the notion of a shader "program", which serves as the interface between the main program running on the CPU and the shaders, which are executed on the GPU.

segment.source: Shaders are compiled (or loaded from compiled sources) and associated with a program, which enables execution on the GPU.
segment.target: Shaders are compiled (or loaded from compiled sources) and associated with a program, which enables execution on the GPU.

segment.source: Direct3D does not have the concept of a shader program object.
segment.target: Direct3D does not have the concept of a shader program object.

segment.source: Rather, the shaders are created when one of the shader creation methods on the ID3D11Device interface (such as ID3D11Device::CreateVertexShader or ID3D11Device::CreatePixelShader) is called.
segment.target: Rather, the shaders are created when one of the shader creation methods on the ID3D11Device interface (such as ID3D11Device::CreateVertexShader or ID3D11Device::CreatePixelShader) is called.

segment.source: To set the shaders for the current drawing context, we provide them to corresponding ID3D11DeviceContext with a set shader method, such as ID3D11DeviceContext::VSSetShader for the vertex shader or ID3D11DeviceContext::PSSetShader for the fragment shader.

segment.source: Direct3D does not have the concept of an "attribute" or a "uniform" in the same sense (or, at least, it does not share this syntax).

segment.source: Rather, it has constant buffers, represented as Direct3D subresources -- resources that are shared between the main program and the shader programs.
segment.target: Rather, it has constant buffers, represented as Direct3D subresources -- resources that are shared between the main program and the shader programs.

segment.source: Some of these subresources, such as vertex positions and colors, are described as HLSL semantics.
segment.target: Some of these subresources, such as vertex positions and colors, are described as HLSL semantics.
